titleStmt.title: Loues garlan[d] or, Posies for rings, hand-ke[r]chers, and cloues and such pretty tokens that louers sent their loues. Reade, skanne, the iudge.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by N. O[kes] for Iohn Spencer, are to be sold at his shop on London Bridge,

notesStmt.note: Imperfect; quire A only; margins cropped, affecting text and signatures.
Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-09 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2010-10 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p:
Loues Garland OR, Poſies for Rings, Hand-ke •
chers, and Gloues; And ſuch pretty Tokens that Louers ſend their Loues.
LONDON, Printed by N. O. for IOHN SPENCER, 〈◊〉 are to be ſold at his ſhop on London Bridge. 1624.

div.head: The Poſie of a Handkercher from a Young man to his Loue.
Another ſignifying the mutuall loue that ſhould be betweene man and wife.
Another from a doubtfull Louer.
div.l: By Cupids bow, my weale or woe.

div.head:
A Poſie ſent with a paire of Gloues,
ſhewing what a young man ſhould moſt reſpect in his choyce.
The Poſie of a Ring from a croſt Lover.
A young man to his Loue, wrought in a Skarfe.
Her kind anſwere.
div.l: For thou haſt ſuch a heart

div.head: The Poſie of a Handkercher from a young man to his Loue.
div.l: heele do as much for you.

div.head: Another where the Louer doth proteſt, and requeſt.
div.l: Hand, heart, and all I haue is thine:
Hand, heart, and all thou haſt, be mine.

div.head: Another.
div.l: As you finde me, minde me.

div.head: The Poſie of a Young man to his Loue, ſhewing the ſimplicity, and truth of Loue.
Another from a Louer, far from his Loue.
A Poſie in a Ring.
div.l: Be true to me, as I to thee.

div.head: Another ſent with a paire of Bracelets.
div.l: Chaſt and pure is my Suſana.

div.head: The Poſie of a young man to his Loue, ſhewing her what a woman ſhould be.
div.l: If woman ſhould to man be woe,
She ſhould not be what God did make her,
That was to be a helper ſo,
God then did giue, man now doth take her.

div.head: The Poſie of a mayd caſt off, expreſſing how lightly ſhe takes it.
div.l: Tell him that had my heart in chace,
And now at other game doth flye,
Gréen ſicknes nere ſhal ſpoile my face,
Nor puling heigh-hoes wet mine eye.

div.head: The Poſie of a Ring.
div.l: I do reioyce, in thee my choyce.

div.head: A Poſie of a ſcornfull Louer.
div.l: Since thy hot loue ſof quickly's done,
Do thou but go, Ile ſtriue to runne.

div.head: A Poſie ſhewing man and wife to be one.
div.l: Fleſh of my fleſh, hone of my bone,
From onemade two, is two made one.

div.head: Another.
div.l: If you deny, I wiſh to dye.

div.head: Another.
div.l: I liue if I: if no I dye.

div.head: Another.
div.l: No bitter ſmart, can change my heart.

div.head: Another.
div.l: Not luſt but loue: as time ſhall prooue.

div.head: Another.
div.l: To loue as I do thee;
Is to loue none but mee.

div.head: A Poſie ſent by a young man to his loue in a Handkercher, in which was wrought the faſhion of a heart with winges.
div.l: Of all had things, a heart with wings
And he that meets, with one ſo fleets,

div.head: The maydens reply in a Handkercher, in which was the ſhape of a Heart, with an arrow through it.
div.l: A flying heart, a piercing dart,
So be it with me, if I from thee

div.head: Another.
div.l: Be true to me, as I to thee.

div.head: A young mayd to he Loue in a Skarfe.
div.l: She that of all doth loue thee deereſt,
Doth ſend the this which as yu wearſt;
And oft do • looke on, thinke on mee,
As I by thine do thinke on thee.

div.head: From a young man to his loue, wrought in a ſilke girdle.
div.l: Till death deuide, what ere betide.

div.head: Another.
div.l: The worlds a Lottery, my prize
A loue that's faire, as chaſte, as wiſe.

div.head: A young man to his Loue, deſcribing the power and euer-flouriſhing vertue of Loue.
div.l: Loue til beomes day in his prime,
Though't haue beene as long as time,
Yet ſtill is young, though time be old.

div.head: From a young man to his Loue, ſhewing that vertue and beauty ſhould go together.
div.l: Thy Beauty much, thy Vertue ſuch,
The firſt alone, is worſe then none,

div.head: The Poſie of a pitifull Louer writ in a Ribon Cornation three peny broad, and wound about a faire branch of Roſe-mary, vpon which he witely playes thus.
div.l: Roſe mary Roſe, I ſend to thee,
In hope that thou wilt marry mee:

div.head: The ſweet reply in a conceit of the ſame &c. ſent by Roſe with a Vyoll of Roſe-water of her owne making.
div.l: ſweete Roſe doth let thee ſes,
Thy loues as ſweet to her,

div.head: A wanton Louers wiſh ſent in a Handkercher with a Cupid wrought in the middle.
div.l: To me by farre more faire

div.head: For a Ring.
div.l: Deſire like fire, doth ſtill aſpire.

div.head: A Poſie ſent with a paire of Bracelets.
div.l: Mine eye did ſee, my heart did chooſe,
True loue doth binde, till death doth

div.head: Another ſent with a ſilke girdle.
div.l: Accept of this, my heart withall:
My loue is great, though this be ſmall.

div.head: Another ſent with a paire of rich gloues.
div.l: The hearts not where it liues,

div.head: Another.
div.l: My heart and I, vntill I dye.
Not two, but one, till life be gone.

div.head: A Louers conceite vpon Bracelet, and Parclet, ſent with a paire of amber Bracelets.
div.l: Bracelets Ile giue, en brace lets euer:
Let Partlets go, for part lets neuer.

div.head: A Poſie written by one Simon Mattocke Sexton of great Wambleton, in the behalfe of a youth of his Parriſh, to the faireſt Milke-mayde in the next, ſent to her pinn'd to the Orange tawny top of a very faire paire of gloues of ſix pence.
div.l: My Loue is ſet, to loue thee ſtill,
Then Nan remember thou thy will:
That William, good will to thee,
I long haue borne, beare yu with me

div.head: Her anſwer in a faire Romiſh letter, lapt vp hand ſomely, and bound about with a cruell long Codpeece poynt.
div.l: I hope my Willy makes no doubt,
I take in others keepe him out:
No for thy ſake I looke my Wilkin
Pale as the payle, I vſe to milke in.
